prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Continuum and DCO+ in Serpens Main and Serpens South

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We will configure three of the basebands for continuum detections. The fourth baseband will be used to detect DCO+(3-2).
Continuum: The three continuum basebands will be configured to the largest available bandwidth to maximize our continuum sensitivity. All three basebands will use the setup with 31.250 MHz channels to decrease the data rate and make the continuum analysis easier. All of this continuum bandwidth is needed to maximize our ability to detect dust emission from faint protostars in Serpens.
Spectral line: We will attempt to detect DCO+(3-2) from protostars in Serpens. We configure the fourth baseband to a 117.188 MHz bandwidth and 61.035 kHz channel resolution to detect and resolve this line, which is expected to have linewidths of 0.3 - 1 km/s at FWHM.

We carefully chose our target angular resolution and largest angular scale to balance the desire to resolve the disk around these protostars with the need to be sensitive to a significant fraction of the envelope emission surrounding them. We also wanted to do both of these things using a single 12-m configuration, to minimize the time required. Our targets are at a distance of 415 pc in Serpens Main and Serpens South. At this distance, an angular resolution of 0.6" corresponds to ~250 AU, which is roughly the expected disk diameter around the target YSOs, and a largest angular scale of 10" corresponds to ~4000 AU, which covers a substantial part of the envelopes around the YSOs. We can capture this full range of spatial scales with the C36-3 configuration at Band 6.

We are targeting a mass sensitivity of 1/1000th solar mass to make major improvements over past work and to seek to detect sub-solar luminosity sources. Assuming a dust temperature of 25 K and that the entire target source is covered by a single beam, the 220 GHz flux should be ~0.5 mJy at the distance of Serpens (415 pc). To achieve a 5-sigma detection, we request an RMS of 0.1 mJy/beam for the continuum observations. This requires an observing time of 2.02 minutes per pointing with 3 bands set at 1.875 GHz.
For our secondary science objective, the DCO+ line observations, we will get in 2.02 minutes of observing time an rms of about 0.2 K assuming a 0.16 km/s channel width, and a tapered spatial resolution 1.5". We are letting our time requirement be driven by our primary goal - the continuum.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
We propose to study the disk and envelope properties of YSOs in the dense star forming environments of Serpens Main and Serpens South -two young clusters, one with an age of 100,000-200,000 years and the other around 2 million years. We will survey 51 known and suspected YSOs in Serpens Main and 44 in Serpens South with 0.6" resolution in the continuum at 220 GHZ and the DCO+ J=3-2 line. We have chosen a combination of resolution and spatial frequency coverage which will allow us to measure the disk mass (inside 250 AU) and envelope mass (inside 4000 AU) in these sources. Even with 2 minute integrations per source, we can improve on previous studies of these regions by nearly a factor of 100 in mass sensitivity and a factor of 9 in resolution.
The results will reveal how much circumstellar mass and its distribution varies with age and YSO luminosity. The requested observations are deep enough that we hope to detect circumstellar mass associated with significantly sub-solar luminosity objects, allowing identifications of new YSOs in the cluster.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2012.1.00368.S Revealing the Density and Kinematic Structure in the Serpens Active Star Formation Region PI: Lee Mundy Status: This Cycle 1 project is being observed in Cycle 2. At the time of this proposal submission, ACA data has not yet been collected. We have done preliminary data analysis and show continuum results in this proposal.
